summary: Email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in US v. Maxwell regarding discovery issues, specifically concerning the production and review of thousands of images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices and properties. The correspondence details technical problems with accessing files, disputes over classification of 'Highly Confidential' materials, and logistical arrangements for evidence review.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with prosecutors about significant discovery deficiencies, including unviewable photos, missing metadata, and access to 'Highly Confidential' materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He is the primary government correspondent in this chain, providing updates on FBI evidence review, de-designation of materials, and logistical arrangements for defense access.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the correspondence regarding discovery issues.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US v. Maxwell. The discovery materials, including images from Epstein's residences, are being produced for her review at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier. The discovery materials in question were seized from his New York residence and devices, forming a core part of the evidence against Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is a defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by her advocacy for Maxwell's access to discovery materials.
The document references evidence seized from Epstein's properties that is central to the case against Maxwell, implying their alleged criminal association.
They are opposing counsel in US v. Maxwell, engaged in a detailed back-and-forth regarding discovery obligations, evidence classification, and access for the defense.
Both are defense attorneys on Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team, as both are copied on the discovery correspondence.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021, as mentioned in the context of discovery deadlines.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: The defense team traveled to New York to review evidence in the government's possession, including 'Highly Confidential' materials on hard drives. They encountered technical problems with file readers.

events.title: Hard Drive Production for Defense
events.description: Prosecutors are in the process of copying a production of images (including de-designated and previously produced files) onto hard drives for delivery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel.

locations: New York, NY (Southern District of New York, Epstein's New York residence, 500 Pearl Street)
Denver, CO (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman law office, FBI field office for evidence review)
Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) (where Ghislaine Maxwell is held)
Epstein's private island (referenced regarding a 3D 'lazer scan' file)
keyFacts: The government possesses approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, with thousands previously classified as 'Highly Confidential' due to nudity.

A significant discrepancy exists between an initial verbal estimate of ~2,100 'nude' images from Epstein's devices and an FBI report indicating ~33,747 'HC' images and 895 'HC' videos from a CART-processed evidence review.

The defense reports widespread technical problems with the discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, unviewable photo formats, and an inability to match images with their associated data, hindering case preparation.

Prosecutors are arranging for the FBI to ship certain 'Highly Confidential' evidence (hard drives and a pair of boots) to Colorado for the defense to review in person at an FBI office, but under strict supervision.

The defense is challenging the government's broad definition of 'Highly Confidential' material, arguing it includes non-pornographic adult nudity and imposes an undue burden, unlike typical child pornography cases.
